questions.q: What defines systolic blood pressure?
questions.rationale: Systole represents the maximal force of blood exerted against the artery walls during contraction.

questions.q: What does a widening pulse pressure indicate?
questions.rationale: A widening pulse pressure (higher systolic, lower diastolic) is a classic sign of Increased ICP (Cushing's Triad).

questions.q: How do you distinguish Angina from MI?
questions.rationale: The key diagnostic difference clinically is that Angina Pectoris is relieved by Nitroglycerin and rest, whereas MI pain is not.

questions.q: What is the most common side effect of Nitroglycerin?
questions.rationale: Nitroglycerin causes massive vasodilation, leading to cerebral vasodilation (Headache) and systemic hypotension.

questions.q: What must be assessed before giving Digoxin?
questions.rationale: Digoxin slows the heart rate; giving it to a bradycardic patient can cause life-threatening heart block.

questions.q: What is a classic sign of Left-Sided Heart Failure?
questions.rationale: Left-sided failure backs fluid up into the Lungs (Left = Lungs), causing crackles and dyspnea.

questions.q: What are the early signs of hypovolemic shock?
questions.rationale: The body compensates for low volume by increasing Heart Rate and Respiratory Rate to maintain perfusion.

questions.q: If you deflate a cuff TOO SLOWLY, the reading will be:
questions.rationale: Slow deflation allows venous congestion to build up, falsely increasing the resistance and the reading.

questions.q: Vasoconstriction will _____ blood pressure.
questions.rationale: Narrowing the vessels increases resistance, which directly increases blood pressure.

questions.q: Vasodilation will _____ blood pressure.
questions.rationale: Widening the vessels decreases resistance, which lowers blood pressure.

questions.q: Shock will _____ blood pressure.
questions.rationale: Loss of volume (hypovolemia) leads to a drop in pressure.

questions.q: Increased intracranial pressure will _____ the pulse pressure.
questions.rationale: Cushing's reflex causes systolic BP to rise to overcome ICP, widening the pulse pressure.

questions.q: What causes angina pectoris?
questions.rationale: Angina is ischemic pain caused by a mismatch between oxygen supply and demand.

questions.q: How many nitroglycerin tabs can you take before calling the doctor?
questions.rationale: Standard protocol is one tab every 5 minutes up to 3 doses. If pain persists, it may be an MI.

questions.q: By what route do you take nitro?
questions.rationale: Sublingual administration allows rapid absorption into the bloodstream, bypassing the liver.

questions.q: What is the action of nitro?
questions.rationale: Nitro is a potent vasodilator, improving blood flow to the heart muscle.

questions.q: What precaution must the nurse take when administering topical nitro paste?
questions.rationale: The medication can be absorbed through the nurse's skin, causing a severe headache.

questions.q: What is the #1 symptom of an MI?
options: Severe chest pain unrelieved by rest/nitro
questions.rationale: Pain that does not go away with rest or nitro is the hallmark sign of infarction vs angina.

questions.q: What words will the client use to describe the pain of an MI?
questions.rationale: Ischemic cardiac pain is typically described as pressure or squeezing, not sharp/stabbing.

questions.q: Death due to MI occurs within ___ of symptom onset in 50% of all patients.
questions.rationale: The first hour is the "Golden Hour" due to the high risk of fatal arrhythmias like V-Fib.

questions.q: What pain medication is given for the pain of a MI?
questions.rationale: Morphine reduces pain and anxiety, and also decreases preload (venous return), resting the heart.

questions.q: What is the reason for giving post MI patients ASA?
questions.rationale: Aspirin inhibits platelet clumping, preventing further occlusion of the coronary arteries.

questions.q: The 3 most common complications after MI are...
questions.rationale: Arrhythmias (electrical), CHF (pump failure), and Shock (severe failure) are direct consequences of heart muscle death.

questions.q: What drug is used to treat PVCs after an MI?
questions.rationale: Lidocaine suppresses ventricular irritability (PVCs) which can lead to V-Fib.

questions.q: Which cardiac enzyme rises earliest after an MI?
questions.rationale: Troponin is highly specific to cardiac muscle and rises within 3 hours of injury.

questions.q: Will fluid resuscitation treat cardiogenic shock?
questions.rationale: The pump is broken; adding fluid volume overloads it further. You need drugs to strengthen the pump.

questions.q: Will the client with a MI be nauseated? Diaphoretic?
questions.rationale: Pain and decreased cardiac output trigger the autonomic nervous system, causing sweating and nausea.

questions.q: What is the permanent EKG change seen post MI?
questions.rationale: ST elevation indicates acute injury; pathologic Q waves indicate permanent tissue death.

questions.q: When cardiac output fails, name three ways the heart will try to compensate.
questions.rationale: The heart beats faster (tachycardia) and grows larger (hypertrophy/dilation) to try to pump more blood.

questions.q: Name the three groups of drugs used to treat CHF?
questions.rationale: Diuretics remove fluid, Vasodilators open vessels, and Digoxin strengthens the beat.

questions.q: When during the day should TED hose be applied?
questions.rationale: Apply before legs are dependent (standing) to prevent fluid from pooling.

questions.q: Should you massage the calves of the client with CHF?
questions.rationale: Massaging can dislodge a DVT (deep vein thrombosis), sending it to the lungs (PE).

questions.q: Name the four most common toxic effects of digitalis.
options: Constipation, Dry mouth, Urinary retention, Blurred vision
questions.rationale: Early signs are GI (nausea), late signs are visual (haloes) and cardiac (arrhythmias).

questions.q: What daily measurement best indicates fluid retention?
questions.rationale: Weight gain is the most sensitive and reliable indicator of fluid status.

questions.q: When the client is taking diuretics, what mineral is the CHF client most likely to lose?
questions.rationale: Loop diuretics like Lasix waste potassium, leading to hypokalemia.

questions.q: The best way to prevent thrombophlebitis is:
questions.rationale: Walking pumps the calf muscles, aiding venous return and preventing stasis.

questions.q: What is the primary cause of Buerger's Disease?
questions.rationale: Buerger's disease (Thromboangiitis obliterans) is strongly associated with tobacco use.

questions.q: What triggers a Raynaud's attack?
questions.rationale: Cold causes vasoconstriction, triggering the arterial spasm in fingers/toes.

questions.q: What does a leg with PAD look like?
questions.rationale: Lack of arterial blood flow leads to cool skin, pallor, and loss of hair follicles.

questions.q: What is the normal adult heart rate range?
questions.rationale: Normal sinus rhythm for an adult is 60-100 beats per minute. Below 60 is bradycardia, above 100 is tachycardia.

questions.q: Which chamber of the heart pumps blood to the systemic circulation?
questions.rationale: The left ventricle is the most muscular chamber and pumps oxygenated blood through the aorta to the entire body.

questions.q: What is the first-line drug class for hypertension in a patient with diabetes?
questions.rationale: ACE inhibitors (e.g., Lisinopril) are first-line for diabetic hypertension because they also protect the kidneys from diabetic nephropathy.

questions.q: A client on Heparin has an aPTT of 120 seconds. What should the nurse do first?
options: Stop the infusion and notify the provider
questions.rationale: Normal aPTT is 25-35 seconds; therapeutic range on Heparin is 1.5-2.5x normal. An aPTT of 120 is dangerously high and indicates bleeding risk.

questions.q: What is the antidote for Heparin overdose?
questions.rationale: Protamine sulfate directly neutralizes Heparin. Vitamin K is the antidote for Warfarin, not Heparin.

questions.q: What lab value must be monitored for a client on Warfarin (Coumadin)?
questions.rationale: Warfarin affects the extrinsic pathway, monitored by PT and INR. Therapeutic INR is typically 2-3.

questions.q: What is the antidote for Warfarin overdose?
questions.rationale: Vitamin K reverses the anticoagulant effects of Warfarin by restoring clotting factor production in the liver.

questions.q: Which heart valve separates the left atrium from the left ventricle?
questions.rationale: The mitral valve (bicuspid) is the only valve with two leaflets and separates the left atrium from the left ventricle.

questions.q: What is the primary pacemaker of the heart?
questions.rationale: The SA (sinoatrial) node fires at 60-100 bpm and is the natural pacemaker that initiates each heartbeat.

questions.q: A client develops sudden severe tearing chest pain radiating to the back. What does the nurse suspect?
questions.rationale: A tearing or ripping pain in the chest radiating to the back is the hallmark presentation of aortic dissection, a life-threatening emergency.

questions.q: What position should a client with CHF be placed in to ease breathing?
questions.rationale: High Fowler's (head of bed elevated 60-90 degrees) reduces venous return to the heart and allows the diaphragm to drop, improving lung expansion.

questions.q: What does the S3 heart sound indicate in an adult?
questions.rationale: An S3 (ventricular gallop) in an adult indicates fluid overload and is an early sign of heart failure. It is normal in children and young adults.

questions.q: Which electrolyte imbalance increases the risk of Digoxin toxicity?
questions.rationale: Low potassium levels allow Digoxin to bind more readily to cardiac cells, increasing the risk of fatal arrhythmias.

questions.q: What type of shock causes warm, flushed skin and bounding pulses?
questions.rationale: Early septic shock causes massive vasodilation resulting in warm, flushed skin and bounding pulses ("warm shock" phase).

questions.q: What is the classic sign of cardiac tamponade?
questions.rationale: Beck's triad consists of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular vein distension (JVD), indicating fluid compressing the heart.

questions.q: What EKG rhythm shows no discernible P waves and an irregularly irregular rhythm?
questions.rationale: Atrial fibrillation is characterized by chaotic atrial activity (no organized P waves) and an irregularly irregular ventricular response.

questions.q: What is the greatest risk of atrial fibrillation?
questions.rationale: Blood pools in the quivering atria, forming clots that can embolize to the brain causing a stroke. This is why A-fib patients are anticoagulated.

questions.q: What drug is given to treat symptomatic bradycardia?
questions.rationale: Atropine blocks the vagus nerve (parasympathetic), allowing the heart rate to increase.

questions.q: What is the normal cardiac output for an adult?
questions.rationale: Normal cardiac output is approximately 4-8 L/min (calculated as Heart Rate x Stroke Volume).

questions.q: What nursing intervention is highest priority for a client in V-Fib?
questions.rationale: Ventricular fibrillation is a lethal rhythm with no cardiac output. Immediate CPR and defibrillation are the only interventions that save lives.

questions.q: What is pulsus paradoxus?
options: A drop in systolic BP >10 mmHg during inspiration
A rise in BP during inspiration
Absence of pulse in lower extremities
questions.rationale: Pulsus paradoxus (>10 mmHg systolic drop on inspiration) is seen in cardiac tamponade, severe asthma, and constrictive pericarditis.

questions.q: What is the hallmark sign of Right-Sided Heart Failure?
questions.rationale: Right-sided failure backs blood into the systemic venous system, causing JVD, hepatomegaly, peripheral edema, and ascites.

questions.q: What teaching should the nurse provide about Warfarin and diet?
questions.rationale: Vitamin K counteracts Warfarin. Patients should not eliminate it but keep intake consistent so the dosage remains effective and predictable.

questions.q: What is the Troponin level used to diagnose?
questions.rationale: Troponin I and T are proteins released when cardiac muscle cells die. Elevated levels confirm myocardial damage/infarction.

questions.q: What position should a client be in for a central venous pressure (CVP) reading?
questions.rationale: CVP is measured with the client supine and the transducer leveled at the phlebostatic axis (4th intercostal space, midaxillary line).

questions.q: A low CVP reading indicates:
questions.rationale: Normal CVP is 2-6 mmHg. A low reading suggests decreased blood volume (hypovolemia) requiring fluid replacement.

questions.q: What does an elevated BNP (B-type natriuretic peptide) indicate?
questions.rationale: BNP is released by the ventricles in response to increased wall stretch from volume overload. Elevated BNP is a key marker of heart failure.

questions.q: What is the priority nursing action when a client develops chest pain?
options: Place on oxygen and assess vital signs
questions.rationale: ABCs come first: ensure oxygenation and assess hemodynamic stability. Then obtain an EKG and notify the provider.

questions.q: What does MONA stand for in acute MI management?
questions.rationale: MONA is the classic mnemonic for acute MI interventions: Morphine (pain), Oxygen (perfusion), Nitroglycerin (vasodilation), Aspirin (antiplatelet).

questions.q: After a cardiac catheterization, what should the nurse assess at the insertion site?
questions.rationale: Post-cath, the nurse checks for hemorrhage at the puncture site, hematoma formation, and circulation distal to the site (pulses, color, sensation).

questions.q: After cardiac catheterization via the femoral artery, how long must the client keep the leg straight?
questions.rationale: The affected leg must remain straight for 4-6 hours to prevent bleeding from the femoral artery puncture site.

questions.q: What is the therapeutic INR range for a client on Warfarin for atrial fibrillation?
questions.rationale: The target INR for most conditions including A-fib is 2.0-3.0. Higher ranges (2.5-3.5) are used for mechanical heart valves.

questions.q: What rhythm is characterized by a sawtooth pattern on EKG?
questions.rationale: Atrial flutter produces a distinctive sawtooth (F-wave) pattern due to rapid, organized atrial depolarization at 250-350 bpm.

questions.q: What drug is the first-line treatment for SVT (supraventricular tachycardia)?
questions.rationale: Adenosine is given as a rapid IV push to briefly block the AV node, interrupting the re-entry circuit causing SVT.

questions.q: How should Adenosine be administered?
options: Rapid IV push followed by a saline flush
questions.rationale: Adenosine has a half-life of <10 seconds and must be given as a rapid IV push (1-2 seconds) followed by an immediate 20 mL saline flush.

questions.q: Which heart block requires an immediate pacemaker?
questions.rationale: Mobitz Type II has a high risk of progressing to complete heart block. Unlike Type I, it occurs below the AV node and requires pacing.

questions.q: What is the characteristic of Third-Degree (Complete) Heart Block on EKG?
options: No relationship between P waves and QRS complexes
questions.rationale: In complete heart block, the atria and ventricles fire independently. P waves and QRS complexes have no association (AV dissociation).

questions.q: What is the priority intervention for a client in asystole?
questions.rationale: Asystole (flatline) is NOT a shockable rhythm. Treatment is high-quality CPR and Epinephrine every 3-5 minutes per ACLS protocol.

questions.q: What is the difference between defibrillation and cardioversion?
options: Defibrillation is synchronized; cardioversion is unsynchronized
Cardioversion is synchronized; defibrillation is unsynchronized
questions.rationale: Synchronized cardioversion delivers a shock timed to the R wave to avoid hitting the T wave (vulnerable period). Defibrillation delivers an unsynchronized shock for pulseless V-Tach and V-Fib.

questions.q: What is a normal blood pressure for an adult?
questions.rationale: Normal adult BP is <120/80 mmHg. Elevated is 120-129/<80. Stage 1 HTN is 130-139/80-89. Stage 2 HTN is ≥140/≥90.

questions.q: What are the classic signs of a DVT (deep vein thrombosis)?
options: Cool, pale extremity with absent pulse
Unilateral leg swelling, warmth, redness, pain
questions.rationale: DVT presents with unilateral swelling, warmth, redness, and calf pain (positive Homans' sign is no longer recommended but may still appear on NCLEX).

questions.q: What is the most dangerous complication of DVT?
questions.rationale: A clot can break loose from the deep veins and travel to the lungs, causing a life-threatening pulmonary embolism.

questions.q: What is intermittent claudication?
options: Leg pain during walking that resolves with rest
Swelling of the ankles at night
questions.rationale: Intermittent claudication is the hallmark symptom of PAD—cramping leg pain caused by insufficient arterial blood flow during exercise that resolves with rest.

questions.q: What is the ankle-brachial index (ABI) used to assess?
questions.rationale: ABI compares ankle systolic pressure to brachial systolic pressure. An ABI <0.9 indicates peripheral arterial disease.

questions.q: What position should a client with PAD place their legs in?
questions.rationale: Gravity assists arterial blood flow to the legs. Elevating the legs worsens ischemic pain in PAD (unlike venous insufficiency where elevation helps).

questions.q: What differentiates arterial ulcers from venous ulcers?
options: Arterial ulcers are painless; venous are painful
Arterial ulcers are deep with pale base; venous are shallow with dark red base
Venous ulcers are on the toes; arterial are on the ankle
questions.rationale: Arterial ulcers are deep, round, pale, and very painful (usually on toes/feet). Venous ulcers are shallow, irregular, ruddy, with moderate pain (usually on medial ankle).

questions.q: What class of drugs ends in '-pril'?
questions.rationale: ACE inhibitors (e.g., Lisinopril, Enalapril, Captopril) all end in '-pril.' They block conversion of Angiotensin I to Angiotensin II.

questions.q: What is the most common side effect of ACE inhibitors?
questions.rationale: ACE inhibitors cause a dry, hacking cough due to accumulation of bradykinin. If intolerable, switch to an ARB ('-sartan').

questions.q: What life-threatening side effect of ACE inhibitors requires immediate intervention?
questions.rationale: Angioedema (swelling of tongue, lips, throat) can cause airway obstruction and is a medical emergency requiring the drug to be stopped immediately.

questions.q: What class of drugs ends in '-olol'?
questions.rationale: Beta blockers (e.g., Metoprolol, Atenolol, Propranolol) end in '-olol.' They decrease heart rate and blood pressure by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors.

questions.q: Why should Beta blockers not be stopped abruptly?
options: It leads to rebound tachycardia and hypertension
questions.rationale: Abrupt withdrawal causes rebound sympathetic activation, leading to dangerous tachycardia, hypertension, and potential MI. Always taper gradually.

questions.q: What is the priority nursing assessment for a client on an IV Nitroglycerin drip?
questions.rationale: IV Nitroglycerin causes potent vasodilation leading to hypotension. Continuous BP monitoring is essential to prevent dangerously low pressures.

questions.q: What is orthostatic (postural) hypotension?
options: Consistently high BP in both arms
BP drop ≥20 systolic or ≥10 diastolic within 3 minutes of standing
High BP only when in a clinic setting
BP difference between upper and lower extremities
questions.rationale: Orthostatic hypotension is a significant drop in BP upon position change (lying to sitting to standing). It increases fall risk, especially with antihypertensives.

questions.q: What teaching should the nurse give to prevent orthostatic hypotension?
options: Stand up quickly to get blood flowing
Change positions slowly (dangle feet before standing)
Take all BP meds at bedtime
questions.rationale: Changing positions slowly allows the cardiovascular system time to compensate, preventing dizziness, falls, and syncope.

questions.q: What is the classic triad of Cushing's reflex in increased ICP?
questions.rationale: Cushing's triad (widened pulse pressure/hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respirations) is a late, ominous sign of brainstem herniation from increased ICP.

questions.q: What is the difference between stable and unstable angina?
options: Unstable angina is predictable with exertion
Unstable angina occurs at rest and is unpredictable
questions.rationale: Stable angina is predictable (occurs with exertion, relieved by rest/nitro). Unstable angina is unpredictable, can occur at rest, and signals impending MI.

questions.q: What diet modification is most important for a client with heart failure?
questions.rationale: Sodium causes water retention, worsening fluid overload in heart failure. A 2-gram sodium diet is typically prescribed.

questions.q: What is the expected finding when auscultating over a stenotic valve?
questions.rationale: A stenotic (narrowed) valve creates turbulent blood flow, producing an audible murmur during auscultation.

questions.q: A client with an acute MI is diaphoretic, hypotensive, and tachycardic. What complication does the nurse suspect?
questions.rationale: Cardiogenic shock occurs when the damaged myocardium can no longer maintain adequate cardiac output, leading to hypotension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and altered mental status.

questions.q: What are the signs of pericarditis?
options: Sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breathing and lying flat
Tearing pain radiating to the back
questions.rationale: Pericarditis causes sharp, pleuritic chest pain that worsens with inspiration and supine position, and improves when leaning forward.

questions.q: What is the hallmark auscultation finding in pericarditis?
questions.rationale: The pericardial friction rub is a scratching, grating sound caused by inflamed pericardial layers rubbing together. It is best heard with the client leaning forward.

questions.q: Calcium channel blockers are often described as:
questions.rationale: CCBs relax and slow the heart — negative inotropic, chronotropic, and dromotropic effects. Often called 'valium for the heart.'

questions.q: Which calcium channel blocker is the STRONGEST vasodilator and most likely to cause headache?
questions.rationale: Nifedipine (Procardia) is the most potent vasodilator among CCBs, making it the most likely to cause the H-H side effects (Headache, Hypotension).

questions.q: A patient on diltiazem has a blood pressure of 86/52. The nurse should:
options: Hold the dose and notify the provider
Give an extra dose for rapid effect
Recheck BP in 2 hours then give dose
questions.rationale: SBP below 90 means hold the CCB. Diltiazem causes vasodilation and further BP drop would be dangerous. Notify the provider.

questions.q: The 'A, AA, AAA' mnemonic for CCBs refers to their use as:
questions.rationale: CCBs serve three clinical roles: A (Antianginal), AA (Antiarrhythmic), AAA (Antihypertensive).

questions.q: A rhythm strip shows 'bizarre' wide QRS complexes at a regular rate. This is most likely:
questions.rationale: V-Tach is characterized by 'bizarre' wide QRS complexes. The key word 'bizarre' with wide QRS = ventricular origin.

questions.q: A flat line on the cardiac monitor with no QRS complexes indicates:
questions.rationale: A flat line with no electrical activity is asystole. It is a lethal rhythm with no cardiac output. Treat with CPR and epinephrine — do NOT defibrillate.

questions.q: Which rhythm has a 'sawtooth' pattern of P-waves?
questions.rationale: Atrial flutter has a characteristic 'sawtooth' or picket-fence pattern of rapid P-wave depolarization, typically at a rate of 250-350 bpm.

questions.q: A patient in asystole should receive which treatment?
questions.rationale: Asystole = flat line = no rhythm to shock. Do NOT defibrillate. Provide CPR and administer epinephrine per ACLS protocol.

questions.q: A patient on the monitor shows ventricular tachycardia. The nurse should FIRST:
questions.rationale: V-Tach MAY have a pulse. Always check for a pulse first. Pulseless V-Tach = defibrillate. V-Tach WITH pulse = treat with amiodarone or lidocaine.

questions.q: Without cardiac output, brain death begins within approximately:
questions.rationale: Without cardiac output there is no brain perfusion. Irreversible brain damage begins within 4-8 minutes, which is why immediate CPR is critical.

questions.q: The ABCD mnemonic for treating atrial dysrhythmias includes all EXCEPT:
questions.rationale: ABCD = Adenosine, Beta-blockers, CCBs, Digoxin (Lanoxin). Dopamine is not part of this mnemonic — it is a vasopressor used for hypotension/bradycardia.

questions.q: Adenosine for SVT must be administered:
options: Rapid IV push with immediate flush
questions.rationale: Adenosine has an extremely short half-life (6-10 seconds) and must be given as a rapid IV push (6mg) followed by an immediate NS flush to reach the heart before metabolism.

questions.q: A patient with atrial fibrillation and asthma should NOT receive which medication?
questions.rationale: Beta-blockers (metoprolol) cause bronchoconstriction and are contraindicated in asthma/COPD. Use CCBs (diltiazem) as an alternative for rate control.

questions.q: The acronym 'TAP' for drug monitoring stands for:
questions.rationale: TAP = Trough (draw before dose), Administer (give the drug), Peak (draw after dose). This sequence ensures accurate therapeutic monitoring.

questions.q: A patient receives vancomycin IV at 0800. The peak level should be drawn at approximately:
questions.rationale: IV drug peak levels are drawn 15-30 minutes after infusion completes, when the drug concentration is at its highest in the blood.

questions.q: A patient on gentamicin has a trough level above therapeutic range. This indicates:
options: The drug is being cleared too quickly
The drug is accumulating and toxicity risk is high
The dose needs to be increased
The drug is at optimal therapeutic levels
questions.rationale: An elevated trough means the drug is not being cleared adequately between doses. This increases the risk of toxicity (ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity for aminoglycosides).
